title: Nitrogen - X3N PES - NA catalyst - N2 vs Z speed

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions about some of the properties and reactions of nitrogen.

A scientist heats a sample of a pure nonmetal, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, in a closed container containing pure nitrogen gas, <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction proceeds to completion. The unbalanced chemical equation for the reaction appears below.

<math alttext="An unbalanced chemical equation with three coefficients, labeled lowercase a through c, as follows. lowercase a , Q, plus lowercase b, N 2, react to produce, lowercase c, N 2 Q 2." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> Q</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>c</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Give the correct value of each stoichiometric coefficient for the reaction.

<math alttext="a equals " overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="b equals " overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="c equals " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions about some of the properties and reactions of nitrogen.

A scientist heats a sample of a pure nonmetal, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, in a closed container containing pure nitrogen gas, <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction proceeds to completion. The unbalanced chemical equation for the reaction appears below.

<math alttext="An unbalanced chemical equation with three coefficients, labeled lowercase a through c, as follows. lowercase a , Q, plus lowercase b, N 2, react to produce, lowercase c, N 2 Q 2." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> Q</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>c</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Give the correct value of each stoichiometric coefficient for the reaction.

<math alttext="a equals " overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="b equals " overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="c equals " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

A particulate representation from before and after the reaction is shown below. The contents of the container before the reaction are represented in the box on the left, and the contents of the container after the reaction are shown in the box on the right.

(b) A student claims that <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is the limiting reactant. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

In a different reaction, <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with a pure metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to form the compound <math alttext="X 3 N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Which of the following complete photoelectron spectra could be that of metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your choice.

(d) A student claims that the bonds in <math alttext="X 3 N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are nonpolar covalent. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s hypothesis? Justify your choice.

A new diatomic element, <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, is discovered and is found to have a molar mass of <math alttext="52 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>52</mn><mtext> g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. At high temperatures, elemental <math alttext="A 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="28 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>28</mn><mtext> g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>) to produce the compound <math alttext="N 2 A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in the equation below.
<math alttext="2 N 2 plus A 2, react to produce N 2 A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
(e) Determine the mass of <math alttext="0.50 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N 2 A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The reaction described above part (e) occurs via a two-step mechanism and has a <math alttext="delta H naught of reaction less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) Identify which of the diagrams shown above could represent this reaction. Justify your choice.

(g) Using the diagram selected in part (f), determine the activation energy of the first step of the reaction mechanism in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></math>.
(h) Identify the rate-determining step in the diagram selected in part (f). Justify your choice.

A proposed mechanism for the reaction is shown below.
Step 1: <math alttext="N 2 plus A 2, react to produce 2 N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></math>
Step 2: <math alttext="2 N A plus N 2, react to produce 2 N 2 A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mtext> NA</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext> N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
(i) A student claims that the compound <math alttext="N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a catalyst. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Explain your choice.

The table below lists the properties of three nonmetals.

Substance

Boiling Point

(<math alttext="in kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Heat of Vaporization

(<math alttext="in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Nitrogen, <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
 77
 5.6

Element <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 89
 6.8

Element <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
 27
 1.7

(j) Which sample, <math alttext="2 moles" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> moles</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="10 moles" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> moles</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></math>, requires the greatest amount of energy to vaporize at its boiling point? Justify your answer using information in the table.

(k) Which substance, <math alttext="N 2, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="Z, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, has the stronger attractions among its particles? Justify your answer using information from the table.

The plot below shows the distribution of particle speeds for equimolar amounts of <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and element <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same temperature.

(l) Based on the data in the plot, is the molar mass of <math alttext="N 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, equal to, or less than the molar mass of <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer in terms of kinetic molecular theory.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
